Expectation1: Ensuring financial stability for the family
Situation1: A home loan repayment is due in two months, and the father needs to prepare for it
Situation2: Multiple ID types are acceptable, and spare cards can still be fetched later in the day.
Story:
I woke up early, my mind already racing with numbers. The home loan repayment was looming, and I needed to make sure every cent was accounted for. As a father, I felt the weight of responsibility pressing down on me—my family depended on me to keep a roof over our heads. I checked my wallet, counting the cash and cards, making a mental note to skip any unnecessary expenses this month. 

But today was also election day. As a voter, I knew I had to bring valid identification to the polling station. I had my driver’s license, but my passport and other IDs were tucked away in a drawer at home. The polling place was across town, and I’d planned to go before work, but if I forgot the right ID, I’d have to come back later, losing precious time I could spend working overtime or searching for side gigs to help with the loan.

The expectations clashed in my mind—should I risk the extra trip and lose time I desperately needed for my family’s financial security, or should I focus on my duties as a citizen and make sure my vote counted? The pressure from both sides left me standing in the hallway, keys in hand, heart pounding, unable to move.
